==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Etymology===
From [[桂]] ("''gui'' tree") + [[花]] ("flower"), expanded from [[桂]] to distinguish the osmanthus from the [[肉桂]] ("[[cassia]]", "[[Chinese cinnamon]]").

===Pronunciation===

|c=gwai3 faa1
|mn=kùi-hoe
|cat=n
}}

# [[w:Sweet Osmanthus|sweet osmanthus]] {{qualifier|Osmanthus fragrans}}
[[Image:Osmanthus heterophyllus-hangzhou.JPG|thumb|桂花]]

==Japanese==
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|モクセイ}}
{{ja-kanjitab|けい|か|yomi=on}}
{{wikipedia|Osmanthus fragrans}}
[[Image:Osmanthus_fragrans_(orange_flowers).jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|桂花}}]]

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|yomi=kanon|けいか}}

===Alternative forms===
* {{ja-l|桂華}} {{qualifier|rare}}

===Etymology 1===
{{IPAchar|*/kweːkwa/}} → {{IPAchar|/keːkwa/}} → {{IPAchar|/keːka/}}

From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=けいか}} compound {{m|zh|桂花|tr=kuei<sup>H</sup> xwæ|lit=cassia; osmanthus + flower}}.  Compare modern {{etyl|nan|-}} reading ''kùi-hoe''.

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|けいか|hhira=けいくわ}}

# [[sweet osmanthus]]
# the flowers of the [[sweet osmanthus]]

=====Usage notes=====
The term {{lang|ja|桂花}} is generally reserved for compounds. The tree and the flowers are usually distinguished within Japan between the white-blossoming {{m|ja|銀木犀|tr=ginmokusei||silver osmanthus}} and the orange-blossoming {{m|ja|金木犀|tr=kinmokusei||gold osmanthus}}, with the latter being more popular.

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|桂花茶|けいかちゃ}}: sweet osmanthus tea, a tea flavored with sweet osmanthus blossoms
* {{ja-r|桂花醤|けいかしょう}}: sweet osmanthus sauce, a sweet sauce flavored with sweet osmanthus blossoms
* {{ja-r|桂花陳酒|けいか ちんしゅ}}: sweet osmanthus wine, an aged white wine flavored with sweet osmanthus blossoms
{{der-bottom}}

=====Synonyms=====
* {{ja-r|金木犀|きんもくせい}}: gold [[osmanthus]]
* {{ja-r|銀木犀|ぎんもくせい}}: silver [[osmanthus]]
* {{ja-r|木犀|もくせい}}: ''[[Osmanthus fragrans]]'' in general

===Etymology 2===
From a Chinese legend that the phases of the moon were caused by {{m|cmn|桂}} trees ([[桂#Japanese|''kei'']] in Japanese: general name for ''[[Lauraceae]]'' and other fragrant trees), which would bud, blossom, then drop their flowers and leaves again as if in accelerated seasons. Literally, “''kei'' flower”, likening the phases of the moon to the budding and blooming of the trees.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|けいか|hhira=けいくわ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=けいか|euphemistic}} the [[moon]]
